channel.title: Comments on: Peering into dinosaur skulls â€“ the best application for medical technology

item.title: By: gravelinspector
item.dc:creator: gravelinspector
item.description: A couple of years ago I was looking at the idea of building a 3d printer - a RepRap, or something similar - with the idea of making (scale) models of fossils, endocast cavities etc. The wife vetoed the project, but I tihnk it would have worked, if I could have worked out the tool chain from MRI (or whatever; CT ...) scans to a 3d modelling language that was supported. Having said that, I see a recent (last few days) flurry of lawsuits between the manufacturers of proprietary, closed-source 3d printers. Which makes me glad that I didn't jump in feet-first to just buy a machine and was planning on building my own to open standards. What do you think the market for such products would be - both for research and for teaching?
item.content:encoded:
A couple of years ago I was looking at the idea of building a 3d printer – a RepRap, or something similar – with the idea of making (scale) models of fossils, endocast cavities etc. The wife vetoed the project, but I tihnk it would have worked, if I could have worked out the tool chain from MRI (or whatever; CT …) scans to a 3d modelling language that was supported.
Having said that, I see a recent (last few days) flurry of lawsuits between the manufacturers of proprietary, closed-source 3d printers. Which makes me glad that I didn’t jump in feet-first to just buy a machine and was planning on building my own to open standards.
What do you think the market for such products would be – both for research and for teaching?
